pages.exhaustive_description: Sequoia Capital’s official biography page for partner Julien Bek provides several first-hand details about his upbringing and education.  It says he “learned from my parents, a recruiter and an astrologist,” indicating family professions and an entrepreneurial household.  Bek notes he “had a successful startup while I was in high school” and later founded “a less successful one while I was in a graduate program at Cambridge,” confirming early exposure to entrepreneurship and that he pursued graduate study at the University of Cambridge.  The narrative also states that while at university he spent a summer at a venture-capital firm and first saw pitches from UiPath and Revolut, describing the formative experience that led him toward VC.  The page lists personal interests (private pilot, cooking, sailing) but gives no birth date or school names beyond the reference to “Cambridge.”

mla_citation.page_title: Julien Bek | Sequoia Capital

pages.exhaustive_description: The United Kingdom Companies House officer record for “Julien BEK” (director of dissolved entity Movemice Ltd) supplies verified government-filed personal data.  It lists his date of birth as “August 1993,” gives nationality as “French,” and records his country of residence as the United Kingdom at the time of the 21 September 2015 appointment.  While it does not state his exact birth day or city, it is the only primary source that fixes both month and year of birth and confirms French citizenship, useful for establishing early-life facts.

mla_citation.page_title: Julien BEK personal appointments – Find and update company information

pages.exhaustive_description: Cointime’s investor profile states that Julien Bek “grew up in Geneva, Switzerland,” giving the first concrete city for his childhood.  It also summarizes his education—he “graduated from Warwick Business School and the University of Cambridge”—and re-affirms that he joined Accel in 2018 after Global Founders Capital, with early investments in Revolut and Albert.  The page therefore supplies geographic upbringing (Geneva), confirms undergraduate (Warwick Business School, Management & Finance) and postgraduate (University of Cambridge, Entrepreneurship) credentials, and situates his early career chronology.

mla_citation.page_title: Julien Bek – Person Profile

pages.exhaustive_description: The RAISE Summit 2025 speaker blurb reiterates that Bek “grew up in Switzerland” and “later studied in the UK at the University of Cambridge and Warwick Business School.”  It notes he “first tried his hand as a founder before switching sides initially at GFC & Accel,” providing further confirmation of both education path and early entrepreneurial activity preceding his venture-capital roles.

mla_citation.page_title: Speaker Details: RAISE Summit 2025 – Mr Julien Bek

pages.exhaustive_description: Forbes’ 30 Under 30 profile (Finance, Europe 2021) lists Bek as a “Principal, Accel” and records that the then-27-year-old “holds degrees from Warwick Business School and the University of Cambridge.”  Although brief, the entry independently corroborates his two academic degrees and provides an age datapoint that aligns with the August 1993 birth-month record.

mla_citation.page_title: Julien Bek

pages.exhaustive_description: The Clay aggregated profile cites multiple public-source snippets.  It states Bek is “originally from Geneva, Switzerland,” echoing Cointime, and specifies his undergraduate degree in Management & Finance (Warwick Business School) and postgraduate Entrepreneurship degree (University of Cambridge).  Importantly, it adds a detail about “founding E-clope, one of the first companies in the e-cigarette market,” as an example of his early entrepreneurial ventures beyond the high-school startup mentioned by Sequoia.  The profile also lists personal interests (sailing, cooking, private pilot) and career chronology (Global Founders Capital ➔ Accel ➔ Sequoia).

mla_citation.page_title: Julien Bek – Clay profile

pages.exhaustive_description: The Org’s executive card for Bek confirms the same academic background—“Postgraduate degree in Entrepreneurship from the University of Cambridge and an Undergraduate degree in Management & Finance from the University of Warwick – Warwick Business School.”  While largely duplicative, it strengthens the chain of independent sources affirming his educational credentials and gives specific month/year (September 2023) for his move to Sequoia, supplying timing for the end of his formal education and transition fully into venture capital.

mla_citation.page_title: Julien Bek – Angel Investor at Albert | The Org

pages.exhaustive_description: Sequoia Capital’s official biography for Julien Bek presents the only first-person account of his activities before becoming a professional investor.  In the “Backstory” section he explains that he "had a successful startup while I was in high school and a less successful one while I was in a graduate program at Cambridge," attributing his investment instincts to that early founder experience.  Although the companies are not named, the page confirms (1) continuous entrepreneurship from his teens, (2) direct product-building experience at the University of Cambridge, and (3) that these founder stints preceded any venture-capital employment.  The page also notes that he spent “a summer at a VC firm” during university – establishing a chronological sequence of founder → VC intern → full-time VC, and thereby marking his pre-VC, non-investor roles.  No other corporate employment outside VC is mentioned, indicating those two startups are the entirety of his non-VC career according to Sequoia.

mla_citation.page_title: “Julien Bek | Sequoia Capital.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Clay.earth’s automatically aggregated public profile for Julien Bek adds specific detail to the sketch on Sequoia’s site.  Under “Background and Education” it states that Bek “later launched E-clope, one of the first companies in the e-cigarette market,” explicitly naming the startup he founded while still a student.  The same sentence groups E-clope with “early entrepreneurial ventures” that began in high school, corroborating Sequoia’s claim that he was already a founder before any venture-capital work.  Because Clay surfaces only publicly indexed facts (it cites Sequoia.com and LinkedIn as sources) it is a secondary confirmation that (a) Bek personally launched E-clope and (b) that venture belonged to the emerging European e-cigarette sector, qualifying as a non-VC operating role.

mla_citation.page_title: “Julien Bek.”

pages.exhaustive_description: MarketScreener’s people dossier on Julien Bek supplies another pre-VC company: it lists him as “Founder (01/04/2015) – Smart Outsourcing SL,” an e-commerce/digital-marketing business headquartered in Salamanca, Spain.  The file characterises Smart Outsourcing SL as providing “digital marketing services and products online [and] internet advertising for businesses and startups,” establishing the firm as a services operator rather than an investment vehicle.  The timeline confirms that the founding (April 2015) predates Bek’s first full-time VC job at Global Founders Capital later in 2015, making Smart Outsourcing his second documented operating role outside venture capital.

mla_citation.page_title: “Julien Bek: Positions, Relations and Network – MarketScreener.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Moneyhouse reproduces the Swiss Official Gazette of Commerce (FOSC) filings for E-clope SARL, the e-cigarette company attributed to Bek on other sites.  The record shows: (1) registration date 23 Mar 2011 in Geneva; (2) stated purpose “purchase, sale and trade of high-technology products… notably the marketing of nicotine-free electronic cigarettes”; (3) liquidation completed and company struck off on 18 May 2018; (4) the creditor-contact address during liquidation listed as “Madame Astrid Bek,” indicating family involvement and strengthening the link to Julien Bek.  These registry facts confirm E-clope’s existence, its industry (electronic cigarettes), its lifespan (2011-2018) and its status as a genuine operating business – independently verifying the non-VC venture named in the Clay profile.

mla_citation.page_title: “E-clope SARL, en liquidation à Genève | Moneyhouse.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Official Sequoia Capital profile for Julien Bek. Identifies him as a Seed/Early-stage partner based in London. Narrative “Backstory” explains his entrepreneurial upbringing, a summer job at a VC firm where he first saw UiPath and Revolut pitches, and how that experience honed his ability to spot exceptional founders. The “On the lookout for” section sets out his investment philosophy: enthusiasm for product-centric companies solving everyday problems, excitement about Europe’s AI talent, and desire to help founders compete globally. Gives concrete examples of past or current investments—including Revolut and Melio—and lists present portfolio companies Lemni (2024), Magentic (2024) and Rillet (2025). Demonstrates thematic focus on AI agents, supply-chain tech and AI-native ERP, confirming current role, sector focus and companies backed.

mla_citation.page_title: Julien Bek | Sequoia Capital

pages.exhaustive_description: News report on Sequoia’s hiring of Accel principal Julien Bek as the sixth partner in its London office. Gives the hiring date (article published 6 June 2023) and explains that Bek will join later in 2023. Summarises his career trajectory: five years at Accel (associate → principal) leading the firm’s deal for German startup Slay; earlier experience at Global Founders Capital where he helped back Revolut; board-observer roles at Hopin, BeReal and Primer. Provides context about Sequoia’s European expansion and quotes Luciana Lixandru and Sonali De Rycker praising Bek’s talent. Confirms his move from Accel to Sequoia and highlights his fintech focus.

mla_citation.page_title: Sequoia bolsters London office with sixth partner hire as VC firm unveils radical restructure

pages.exhaustive_description: Forbes 30 Under 30 Europe – Finance profile of Julien Bek. Describes him (age 27 in 2021) as a Principal at Accel focusing on fintech, productivity and collaboration. Notes prior role at Global Founders Capital where he invested in Revolut and Albert. Lists educational credentials (B.A./B.Sc. Warwick Business School; M.A./M.Sc. University of Cambridge). Establishes early-career entry into venture capital (GFC, 2015) and thematic interest in fintech/productivity tools while at Accel.

mla_citation.page_title: Julien Bek

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch article covering Rillet’s $25 million Series A (28 May 2025) led by Sequoia. Quotes partner Julien Bek extensively: he calls the general ledger “the beating heart of the finance function,” explains why VCs once avoided the space and why Rillet changed his mind, and cites metrics he watched (NetSuite replacements) to validate the opportunity. Demonstrates Bek’s current role leading Sequoia’s investment, his interest in AI-driven enterprise software and his analytical approach to fintech/ERP opportunities. Confirms he led the deal and articulates his investment reasoning.

mla_citation.page_title: Rillet raises $25M from Sequoia to automate general ledger systems using AI

pages.exhaustive_description: Rillet press-release blog announcing its $25 million Series A (28 May 2025). Includes a quotation from Julien Bek, identified as “the Sequoia partner who led the firm’s partnership with Rillet,” saying ERP is “one of the largest software categories” yet “virtually untouched,” and praising the founders’ domain expertise and AI-native approach. Confirms Bek’s lead-partner role, shows his thematic focus on AI in finance software, and documents portfolio involvement alongside Sequoia colleagues Roelof Botha and Cornelius Menke.

mla_citation.page_title: Rillet raises $25M Series A from Sequoia Capital to bring AI to mid-market accounting

pages.exhaustive_description: Speaker biography on the RAISE Summit 2025 website. Summarises Julien Bek’s venture-capital career: current Partner at Sequoia Capital in London; works with Dust, Rillet, Tacto and Lemni; earlier experience “switching sides” at Global Founders Capital and Accel, partnering with Revolut, Miro, Attio and BeReal. Provides concise timeline and highlights geographic roots (Switzerland) and education (University of Cambridge and Warwick Business School). Reinforces sequence of firms (GFC → Accel → Sequoia) and breadth of investment focus (AI, consumer, enterprise).

mla_citation.page_title: Speaker Details: RAISE Summit 2025 – Julien Bek

pages.exhaustive_description: Crunchbase’s funding‐round profile for Revolut’s Series A (announced 14 July 2016) lists round details and the full investor roster. Revolut raised a $10 million Series A and, under “Investors,” Julien Bek is named among the 14 participants—direct confirmation that he invested personally at this stage.

mla_citation.page_title: Series A – Revolut – 2016-07-14 – Crunchbase Funding Round Profile

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch’s report announces Revolut’s $10 million Series A led by Balderton on 11 July 2016. It describes the product and confirms the size and timing of the round in which Bek invested.

mla_citation.page_title: “Revolut Grabs $10 Million for Its Mobile Foreign Exchange Service.”

pages.exhaustive_description: This follow-on TechCrunch piece details Revolut’s Series E of $800 million (15 July 2021) led by SoftBank and Tiger Global, valuing the company at $33 billion—evidence of the later-stage outcome of Bek’s early bet.

mla_citation.page_title: “Revolut Confirms a Fresh $800M in Funding at a $33B Valuation to Supercharge Its Financial Services Super App.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Eric Newcomer’s Substack scoop (3 June 2021) reveals that Andreessen Horowitz and Accel agreed to co-lead BeReal’s $30 million Series A, valuing the French social app at about $150 million and citing Accel partner involvement—establishing Bek’s investment while at Accel and the year/size of the round.

mla_citation.page_title: “SCOOP: a16z, Accel Back French Founder’s Photo-Sharing App BeReal.”

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch confirms BeReal’s exit: on 11 June 2024 French publisher Voodoo acquired the company for €500 million. The article gives purchase price, buyer, leadership changes, and user metrics—providing the outcome of Bek’s investment.

mla_citation.page_title: “BeReal Is Being Acquired by Mobile Apps and Games Company Voodoo for €500M.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Steve O’Hear’s TechCrunch story (8 Nov 2018) announces RealtimeBoard (now Miro) raising a $25 million Series A led by Accel. It gives round size, lead investor, company metrics, and product description—evidence for Bek’s 2018 investment while at Accel.

mla_citation.page_title: “RealtimeBoard, a Visual Collaboration Platform for Companies, Raises $25M Led by Accel.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Business Wire press release (5 Jan 2022) describes Miro’s $400 million Series C at a $17.5 billion valuation, lists investors (including Accel) and cumulative funding—showing the significant follow-on outcome of Bek’s earlier Series A.

mla_citation.page_title: “Miro Raises $400M in Series C Funding Round to Accelerate Innovation Through Visual Collaboration in the New Hybrid Workplace.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Business Insider article (8 Sept 2020) reports Melio’s $80 million Series C and notes an earlier $48 million Series B led by Accel in April 2020—pinpointing Bek’s entry round and year.

mla_citation.page_title: “US Fintech Melio Has Raised $80 Million and Says Its Payments Volume Surged 700% During the Pandemic.”

pages.exhaustive_description: PR Newswire release (14 Sept 2021) announces Melio’s $250 million Series D at a $4 billion valuation, listing Accel among existing investors—documenting major follow-on funding.

mla_citation.page_title: “Melio Raises $250M to Fuel Expansion of Its B2B Payments Platform and Forge New Partnerships, Tripling Valuation to $4B.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Business Wire release (31 Oct 2024) details Melio’s $150 million Series E (valuation $2 billion) led by Fiserv with Accel also participating—evidence that the company remained private and continued to raise capital.

mla_citation.page_title: “Melio Raises $150 Million to Expand B2B Payments Partnerships.”

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch’s 29 Nov 2020 article covers Primer’s £14 million ($18.7 million) Series A led by Accel, describing the low-code payments platform and early traction—establishing Bek’s entry round and year.

mla_citation.page_title: “Primer, the Fintech Helping Merchants Consolidate the Payments Stack, Raises £14M Series A.”

pages.exhaustive_description: The follow-up TechCrunch piece (18 Oct 2021) announces Primer’s $50 million Series B at a $425 million valuation, with Accel participating—showing subsequent growth.

mla_citation.page_title: “Primer Raises $50M at a $425M Valuation for a Framework Designed to Help Merchants Build More Powerful Payment Flows.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Business Insider’s 6 June 2023 profile on Bek’s move to Sequoia confirms his prior deal roles: it states he “was involved in the fund’s deal for Revolut” and is “a board observer at… BeReal and fintech Primer,” directly linking him to those investments.

mla_citation.page_title: “Sequoia Bolsters London Office with Sixth Partner Hire as VC Firm Unveils Radical Restructure.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Sequoia’s official blog post (11 Dec 2023) announcing its Series A investment in Tacto is co-authored by Luciana Lixandru, Julien Bek, and Cornelius Menke. It highlights why Sequoia led the €50 million round, confirming Bek’s personal involvement and the 2023 investment year.

mla_citation.page_title: “Partnering with Tacto: Future-Proof Supply Chains.”
mla_citation.author_name: Luciana Lixandru, Julien Bek, and Cornelius Menke

pages.exhaustive_description: Tech.eu news article (12 Dec 2023) reports the €50 million Series A for Tacto led by Sequoia and Index Ventures, giving round size, use of funds, and investor list—complementing Sequoia’s blog with independent confirmation of the amount.

mla_citation.page_title: “Tacto Raises €50M for AI Supply Chain Solutions.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Official biography page for venture-capitalist Julien Bek on Sequoia Capital’s website. Personal-life details include: 1) Parents’ occupations – his mother was an astrologist and his father a recruiter – and the influence they had on his ability to “read people.” 2) He “comes from a family of entrepreneurs,” helping to explain his own early interest in founding companies (a successful high-school startup and a less-successful venture while in graduate school at Cambridge are mentioned). 3) A short ‘Personal Side’ section lists his leisure interests and hobbies verbatim: “Private Pilot; Weekend Cooking; Sailing; Pink Floyd.” These lines confirm he is licensed to fly small aircraft, enjoys cooking on weekends, sails recreationally, and is a fan of the rock band Pink Floyd. No spouse, children, or philanthropic activities are referenced. Copyright notice at bottom shows 2025, but no individual author or publication date is supplied.

mla_citation.page_title: “Julien Bek | Sequoia Capital.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Pay-walled Business Insider news story announcing Bek’s move from Accel to become the sixth partner in Sequoia’s London office. Personal information that can be used in a Wikipedia ‘Personal life’ section: 1) States he is “originally from Geneva, Switzerland,” giving his hometown/early-life location. 2) Quotes colleagues praising his people skills and understanding of founders (useful color for personality, though not strictly ‘personal life’). The article is primarily career-focused and contains no data on family, philanthropy, or private views, but Geneva origin is unique to this source.

mla_citation.page_title: “Sequoia bolsters London office with sixth partner hire as VC firm unveils radical restructure.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Automatically generated Clay Earth profile that aggregates public-web information on Bek. Adds several personal-life datapoints not all found elsewhere: 1) Re-affirms he is “originally from Geneva, Switzerland.” 2) Gives his academic credentials (B.A. Warwick Business School; M.A./M.S. University of Cambridge). 3) Lists personal interests: “sailing and cooking,” and notes that “he is also a private pilot,” echoing the Sequoia page. 4) Mentions an early entrepreneurial foray: he “founded E-clope, one of the first companies in the e-cigarette market,” while still in school – useful anecdote for early-life/hobbies. The page is compiled by Clay; no human by-line or date is provided.

mla_citation.page_title: “Julien Bek.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Forbes ‘30 Under 30 Europe – Finance (2021)’ profile of Julien Bek. Personal-life-relevant facts: 1) Age at time of publication is given: “27-year-old Bek,” implying birth year circa 1993-1994. 2) Confirms current residence/work base: “London, United Kingdom.” 3) Restates his educational background (degrees from Cambridge and Warwick). The short blurb is career-heavy and contains no family or philanthropy details but does supply age and location not explicit elsewhere.

mla_citation.page_title: “Julien Bek.”
